articles.title: APRIL 1985
articles.summary: This document outlines the schedule of astronomy-related events for April and May 1985, primarily organized by the SJAA. Key activities include an Astronomy Day at Vallco Park, multiple indoor and outdoor star parties and field expeditions at locations like Fremont Peak and Henry Coe State Park. The schedule also details a talk on "Lunar Silhouettes," a board meeting, and planning for the 8th Annual Astronomical Auction in May.

articles.title: PRESIDENTS MESSAGE
articles.summary: The new president of the SJAA, Bob Fingerhut, outlines his vision for the club, focusing on continued growth, increased public programs, and securing a non-profit status and club-owned observatory, while also calling for member involvement. The article also announces the 97th Annual Meeting of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific in Flagstaff, featuring a symposium on comets and asteroids, educational workshops, lectures, and tours of astronomical and geological sites.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document features several classified advertisements for astronomical equipment. Items for sale include a new Celestron 5.5" f/1.65 Schmidt Camera and excellent condition Celestron 11X80 Giant Binoculars, both offered by John Gleason. Additionally, a 22" Burk tube is advertised as free to a good home by R. Rose.

articles.title: QUESTION OF THE MONTH
articles.summary: A club member is inquiring about the whereabouts of the club's $1000 CID camera and is looking for Bruce DeGraaf, presumably for information regarding its status.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The article announces the introduction of "Field of View," a new section representing "FROM THE EDITORS DESK." This section will provide members with information regarding both past and current events, likely within an astronomy club or organization, as suggested by the accompanying spiral galaxy illustration.

articles.title: OBSERVATIONS
articles.summary: The author shares personal astrophotography and observing experiences from the previous month, highlighting successful galaxy imaging sessions and plans for observing Halley's Comet. Several SJAA members are also preparing for southern hemisphere trips, including Mauna Kea and Australia, to view the comet, which has a reported brightness discrepancy (23rd magnitude vs. earlier 17th magnitude prediction).

articles.title: NGC 5128 in Centaurus, also known as
articles.summary: The author successfully observed NGC 5128 (Centaurus A) for the first time on February 24th from Fremont Peak, describing it as a large faint hazy ball with a prominent dark lane despite steady seeing conditions. The article also discusses the author's positive experience with a new, cost-effective Kodak E6 HOBBIEST kit for film processing, noting its efficiency and speed for astrophotography compared to other development methods.

articles.title: LUNAR SILHOUETTES
articles.summary: Bob Hewett and Dick Humphries are engaged in a challenging astrophotography project to capture the Lick 36-inch telescope domes silhouetted against the Moon, requiring precise positional planning along Mount Hamilton Road. Dick Humphries will present their efforts and findings in a talk titled "Lunar Silhouettes" at an upcoming Red Cross meeting.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETING BLUE'S
articles.summary: The last General Meeting experienced exceptionally low attendance, with only 15 out of 230 members present to hear Antonio Nafariete speak on optical fabrication for Schmidt corrector plates. To address ongoing low turnout and improve member convenience, it was decided that all future General Meetings will be held on the first Saturday of each month at 8 P.M. at the accessible Los Gatos Red Cross Building.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY DAY
articles.summary: The SJAA is organizing an Astronomy Day event on April 27th at the Vallco shopping mall. This public outreach event will feature an astrophotography contest, a slide show, and various telescope displays, with particular interest expected due to Comet Halley. The SJAA aims to use this event for publicity and invites members to participate by contacting Paul Mancuso.

articles.title: ASTRONOMICAL AUCTION DATE CHANGE
articles.summary: The SJAA Astronomical Auction has been rescheduled from May 4th to May 11th. The organization apologizes for the incorrect date previously published in the EPHEMERIS and encourages early item registration, building on last year's successful event.

articles.title: EQUIPMENT
articles.summary: The article discusses the upcoming 'SKY LOCK' from Lumicon, a dual-axis automatic tracking device designed for astrophotographers, capable of tracking faint stars and expected to launch this summer for $300. Additionally, it reports the unavailability of 'Dew Guns' from astronomical suppliers, suggesting car cigarette lighter-powered hair dryers from recreational vehicle suppliers as an alternative.

articles.title: ASTROPHOTO VI
articles.summary: The article reports on the 6th astrophotographic conference in California, attended by over 200 amateur astronomers, showcasing excellent quality astrophotography, particularly with smaller telescopes. Key presentations included Jean Dragesco's lunar and planetary photographs, Jack Marling's advances in color astrophotography, and Brad Wallis/Robert Provin's insights into optical ray tracing, identifying the Concentric Schmidt Cassegrain as superior for off-axis imaging. Additionally, it announces the upcoming 1985 Riverside Telescope Makers Conference (RTMC).

articles.title: NEW ASSOCIATION OFFICERS
articles.summary: The SJAA Board of Directors has announced its new officers. Bob Fingerhut has been elected as President, with Dave Ambrose serving as Vice President, and Jim Van Nuland continuing as Secretary. The Board of Directors itself will remain unchanged following the recent February elections.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: As the year progresses without new comet discoveries or returns, Halley's Comet stands out as the sole visible comet. It is brightening in the southern sky, moving through the constellations Lupus and Centaurus, and is expected to appear in the evening sky this month.

articles.title: DATE R.A. (1950) DEC. ELONG. MAG.
articles.summary: This document provides ephemeris data for Comet Shoemaker (1984f), detailing its astronomical position and brightness over several dates from late March to early May. It lists the comet's Right Ascension (RA), Declination (DEC), elongation, and visual magnitude, offering essential information for tracking and observing the celestial object. The data is presented in a tabular format, showing the comet's changing coordinates and brightness over a specific period.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND - HALLEY'S COMET
articles.summary: Halley's Comet is currently brightening as it approaches the sun, though it will soon disappear into the solar glare from Earth's perspective. It is presently at magnitude 18, with future visibility expected in the morning sky in December and January at magnitude 13. The article indicates it will provide details on its positions and distances.

articles.title: DATE R.A. (1950) DEC. DIS. TO SUN AND EARTH
articles.summary: This article presents ephemeris data for Comet Halley, detailing its Right Ascension, Declination, and distances to the Sun and Earth from late March to early May. It addresses common misconceptions about the comet's visibility and pronunciation, urging amateur astronomers to actively engage in public outreach. The author emphasizes the importance of planning and hosting public observing sessions and star parties to educate the public and allow them to experience the comet firsthand.

articles.title: SHUTTLE LAUNCH SCHEDULE CHANGED
articles.summary: Mission 51-F has been cancelled due to design flaws in a tracking satellite. Its primary payloads, including Canada's Anik D-1 communication satellite, have been moved to mission 51-D, which will also carry the Syncom A satellite and an electrophoresis machine. Other payloads were moved to mission 51-I, and mission 51-D's launch on Discovery has been rescheduled for no earlier than April 19, following an accident that damaged a payload bay door.

articles.title: VANDENBERG LAUNCH COMPLEX CHECKED OUT
articles.summary: A space shuttle vehicle, including the orbiter Enterprise, was assembled at Vandenberg Launch Complex to verify its facilities. This preparatory step precedes the first operational launch, which is scheduled for no earlier than January 28, 1986, using the orbiter Discovery.

articles.title: CRYSTAL GROWTH EXPERIMENTS TO FLY ON SHUTTLE
articles.summary: Hundreds of protein crystal growth experiments, a collaborative effort between U.S. drug companies, universities, and NASA, are being prepared to fly on the Space Shuttle. This project is being expedited due to its significant potential for key medical and commercial benefits.

articles.title: WILD-2 TARGETED FOR COMET RENDEZVOUS
articles.summary: NASA is proposing a mission to Comet Wild-2, involving a penetrator being dropped onto its surface. This mission is contingent on a new start approval in 1990, with a planned launch date in March 1991.

articles.title: PRESIDENT ISSUES DIRECTIVE ON SPACE LAUNCHERS
articles.summary: A presidential directive mandates increased utilization of the space shuttle by the U.S. Air Force and initiates efforts for a potential second-generation space shuttle. In a related move, the U.S. Air Force has received authorization to purchase ten Titan 34D7 SRM-X boosters to serve as alternatives to military boosters from 1988 through 1993.

articles.title: FY 1986 NASA BUDGET
articles.summary: The article presents two main topics: highlights from the proposed FY 1986 NASA budget, which includes a space station development stretchout, a new orbital maneuvering vehicle, and facility expansions, but no new shuttle orbiter. The second part provides a detailed chronological guide for observing Comet Halley from August 1985 through June 1986, including its predicted magnitude, position, and suggestions for public and dark-sky observing sessions often combined with other celestial events like meteor showers and a total eclipse.

articles.title: DOORS WILL OPEN AT 2:00 PM
articles.summary: This document announces an astronomical swap meet or sale event taking place at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building, with doors opening at 2:00 PM. Attendees can buy and sell a wide array of astronomical equipment, accessories, and related items, from telescopes and eyepieces to books and space art. It is promoted as a significant and enjoyable astronomical event in the Bay Area, encouraging both buyers and sellers to participate.

articles.title: PRE-REGISTRATION INFORMATION
articles.summary: This document outlines the pre-registration process for the 5th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction, urging participants to list astronomical or telescope-making related items for sale. It details how to complete and mail a form with item specifics, minimum prices, and a minimum 10% donation to the SJAA, with all proceeds funding public astronomy education. Pre-registration ensures sellers receive assigned bidder and item numbers to label their goods efficiently and avoid delays on auction day.

articles.title: Directions to the auction:
articles.summary: This document provides directions to an auction located at the Red Cross buildings parking lot (16011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd), accessible via Hwy 17 South and Highway 9. Doors open at 2 PM for item and bidder registration, with registration closing at 5:45 PM before the auction starts promptly at 6 PM. Payment can be made by cash or check, and there is a $1 bidder/seller registration fee, with refreshments available.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK OBSERVATORY ASSOCIATION
articles.summary: The Fremont Peak Observatory Association, founded in 1984 by Bay Area amateur astronomers, aims to build and operate a public observatory at Fremont Peak State Park, a popular dark sky site in California. The project plans to house 30-inch and 22-inch telescopes, offering public programs and private use, with support from the California State Park Department. The association is currently seeking membership and fundraising to reach its $8,000 goal for construction, anticipating the completion of the telescopes in late 1985.

articles.title: All classes of membership are entitled to the following privileges:
articles.summary: This document outlines the privileges associated with all classes of membership in the Fremont Peak Observatory Association (FPOA), including use of facilities, newsletters, and voting rights (with conditions). It details specific rules regarding voting eligibility, a one-time initiation fee for most memberships, and the process to become a 'Charter Member' for those joining by December 1985. All membership dues and donations are tax-deductible, and application instructions are provided.

articles.title: Application For Membership
articles.summary: This document is an application form for membership to the Fremont Peak Observatory Association. It requests the applicant's name, address, and provides several membership categories, including General, Family, Contributing, Sustaining, Life, and Corporate, each with specific annual fees (and a one-time initiation fee for most).

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document outlines the details for general meetings, which occur monthly at 8 PM at the Los Gatos Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California. The location also hosts the SJAA's indoor star parties, and the article provides precise driving directions to the venue.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park, specifically guiding visitors to the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) setup location at the Coulter Camp overflow area. It includes specific highway turns, mileage, and landmarks, culminating with instructions for parking light usage after dark within the park.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK:
articles.summary: This article introduces Grant Ranch County Park as a new observing site for the SJAA, situated on Mt. Hamilton Road. It provides detailed directions for reaching the park from San Jose and essential information regarding the gate, including a combination (4565) for access after sunset and instructions to re-lock it.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to an astronomical observing site located within Henry Coe State Park, accessible from Hwy 101 south near Gilroy. It includes specific driving instructions, the combination for a locked gate (4565), and essential rules for arriving after dark, such as re-locking the gate and using parking lights only.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS is published monthly by the San Jose Astronomical Association, 3905 Calico Ave., San Jose, CA. 95124
articles.summary: This document outlines the publication details for "EPHEMERIS," the monthly newsletter of the San Jose Astronomical Association. It lists the current officers, including the President, Vice-President, Secretary, and Treasurer, along with members of the Board of Directors and the "EPHEMERIS" editor, providing their names and contact information.

articles.title: CLUB TELESCOPES
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) offers three loaner telescopes to its members for two-month periods. Members are responsible for arranging the transfer of the telescope directly with the current holder. It is required to notify a board member or bulletin editor whenever a telescope changes hands.

articles.title: CONCERNING WANT ADS:
articles.summary: The article details the policy for placing astronomical-related want ads in the Ephemeris publication. SJAA members and friends can submit ads free of charge, which will appear for two months unless the editor is notified otherwise. Submission details, including an address, are provided.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines different membership options, including standard, junior, and one bundled with a Sky & Telescope subscription, along with their respective fees, and provides instructions for submission via mail or in-person at an SJAA meeting.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document presents an optional questionnaire designed to gather information about an individual's astronomical interests, such as astro-photography or deep-sky observation, and whether they own a telescope. It also inquires if the individual feels qualified to assist others in specific areas of astronomy. The document concludes with postal information for 'SJAA EPHEMERIS' in San Jose, CA.
